title: Vintage French Soap Label Font
content:
I have seen a lot of these, but I can't figure out what fonts have been used. Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801im_/http:/typophile.com/files/1afree--clip-art-french-labels-gfairy002a_6668.jpg)
author: jadsdrw

comments.content: Are you looking to identify the historical typefaces, or to find contemporary digital fonts that mimic this look?
I'm looking to find digital fonts!

Eau de Cologne and Saigon-Hanoi could be approximated using Chevalier Stripes:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/chevalier-lt/stripes-caps/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/chevalier-lt/stripes-caps/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/chevalier-lt/stripes-caps/")

More to follow....

Distillée par... could be approximated using Epigraph:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/pesic/epigraph/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/pesic/epigraph/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/pesic/epigraph/")

Societé Coloniale could be approximated using Barcelona (copy the curl from the C and graft it onto the Es and Ls):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/")

pour la could be approximated using Adonis Old Style:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/adonis-old-style-sg/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/adonis-old-style-sg/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/adonis-old-style-sg/")
You are a serious font detective! Too bad this would all cost me like $300 :(

Des Grands Magasins could be approximated using Horndon, Mexborough, or Bonning:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/horndon/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/horndon/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/horndon/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/mexborough/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/mexborough/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/mexborough/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/bonning/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/bonning/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/bonning/")

Your chances of finding free fonts that match these closely is practically nil.

Search using the keyword "Victorian" on any free font site, but be aware that many of the fonts you'll find are of questionable provenance, and many are only free for personal--not commercial--use.

Kevin has done a good job rounding up what's available in digital format.  
About the only part remaining is \_DE\_. You can match it with Filmotype Royal [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/royal/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/royal/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/royal/")  
But you should know that the label is not composed of old time fonts as such. Rather it is hand lettering, probably by using lithography.  
For good quality original historic fonts, at no charge you can go through the fonts at [http://abfonts.freehostia.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/abfonts.freehostia.com/ "http://abfonts.freehostia.com/") go to the authors page. Check in particular Character, Claude Pelletier, Toto.

Don

\_Eau Cologne\_ and \_Saigon-Hanoi\_ are not the same design. Note for example the different \_N\_. For a striped font with the \_N\_ in \_Eau Cologne\_, you can use Archive Copperplate Head

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ArchiveCopperplateHeadInUse_5607.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-copperplate-head/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-copperplate-head/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-copperplate-head/") which is an accurate, but indifferent quality, digital rendition of Hermann Ihlenburg's Copperplate from the 19th century. Change the convex inner curve on the terminal serifs for \_E\_, \_L\_, \_C\_, and \_G\_ to a concave inner curve by blanking out the unwanted part, and you have a fair match to \_Eau Cologne\_ .  
Don

To my eye, that style of A should be (more) optically corrected by raising the top a bit higher. Otherwise, it looks undersized - even in [Ihlenburg's original](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219143801/http:/luc.devroye.org/IhlenbergCopperplate--in--MS+J-188.jpg).

Right Mike, I didn't notice...  
Don
If you didn't notice, Don, then it's clearly not as glaring as it appears to me. Rather presumptuous of me to be questioning the design of someone like Hermann Ihlenburg, anyway.
